> Please fix the LGTM warning. Other changes LGTM.

LGTM warning is incorrect. It thinks that `params` variable is unused as it is not used inside inner function. Rather, it is used in outer function. Both outer and inner share same variable, so that fixture teardown can happen properly.

> As we discussed over the phone this test case requires total 5 additional physical slices that most BRCM DUTs do not have. Both TD3 and 7260CX3 platforms have similar FP resources that has only one logical slice (3 physical slices) and 3 disjoint physical slices left.
> So ideally your testcase will require to first delete the DATAACL which frees up a logical slice so that there are resources left for your testcase to run.
> I think perhaps your testcase can first detect if DATAACL is programmed to first delete it before you run your test. At the end of your test you should also restore the DATAACL table so that the testcases that requires DATAACL runs after your testcase will not hit any issue.
> We also need to skip executing your testcase over TH3 platforms (Z9332f) as we know it already has less FP resource than TD3/2 platforms even without DATAACL.
> I like that you are checking syslog for "insufficient resources". But I think if you do all the above and still see this error in syslog you should declare the testcase failure as it is not expected to hit the resource issue if you have already removed DATAACL before your testcase program the new ACL tables.

Thanks for the great suggestion. Will update the test script to remove ```DATAACL``` temporarily.

@gechiang  I added the logic for removing ```DATAACL``` before testing. But I still keep the code that skip test if resource is insufficient. This is to ensure that test won't fail on platform like TH3. Please help to review. Thanks

reviews.body:
As we discussed over the phone this test case requires total 5 additional physical slices that most BRCM DUTs do not have. Both TD3 and 7260CX3 platforms have similar FP resources that has only one logical slice (3 physical slices) and 3 disjoint physical slices left.
So ideally your testcase will require to first delete the DATAACL which frees up a logical slice so that there are resources left for your testcase to run.
I think perhaps your testcase can first detect if DATAACL is programmed to first delete it before you run your test. At the end of your test you should also restore the DATAACL table so that the testcases that requires DATAACL runs after your testcase will not hit any issue.
We also need to skip executing your testcase over TH3 platforms (Z9332f) as we know it already has less FP resource than TD3/2 platforms even without DATAACL.
I like that you are checking syslog for "insufficient resources".  But I think if you do all the above and still see this error in syslog you should declare the testcase failure as it is not expected to hit the resource issue if you have already removed DATAACL before your testcase program the new ACL tables.

@lguohan 
this is correct as in case of platforms not starting from 0, you will get list of indexes 1...x say,
list_sfps = [1, 2 , ..]
when do chassis.get_all_sfps it returns a list of sfps  from DUT for e.g. [sfp1, sfp2 , ...]
current code was doing :
        

>     for i in list_sfps:
>                 sfp = chassis.get_sfp(platform_api_conn, i)
>                 self.expect(sfp and sfp == sfp_list[i], "SFP {} is incorrect".format(i))

so sfp for index 1 will get sfp1 the first sfp in DUT by chassis.get_sfp(platform_api_conn, i)
but sfp_list[1] will get second item in list sfp2 instead of sfp1 , as lists are 0 index based (python list), so to correct this we introduced change  to fix that.
    

>     for i in range(num_sfps):
>             index = list_sfps[i]
>             sfp = chassis.get_sfp(platform_api_conn, index)
>             self.expect(sfp and sfp == sfp_list[i], "SFP {} is incorrect".format(i))

it will always compare value returned by first index from list of indexes and first item in list from get_all_sfps

After this change it would work for both 0 based and 1 based or even if it is non continuous indexes.
Hope this makes it more clear.

> >         self.expect(sfp and sfp == sfp_list[i], "SFP {} is incorrect".format(i))
> > ```
> 
> it will always compare value returned by first index from list of indexes and first item in list from get_all_sfps
> 
> After this change it would work for both 0 based and 1 based or even if it is non continuous indexes.
> Hope this makes it more clear.



> @lguohan
> this is correct as in case of platforms not starting from 0, you will get list of indexes 1...x say,
> list_sfps = [1, 2 , ..]
> when do chassis.get_all_sfps it returns a list of sfps from DUT for e.g. [sfp1, sfp2 , ...]
> current code was doing :
> 
> > ```
> > for i in list_sfps:
> >             sfp = chassis.get_sfp(platform_api_conn, i)
> >             self.expect(sfp and sfp == sfp_list[i], "SFP {} is incorrect".format(i))
> > ```
> 
> so sfp for index 1 will get sfp1 the first sfp in DUT by chassis.get_sfp(platform_api_conn, i)
> but sfp_list[1] will get second item in list sfp2 instead of sfp1 , as lists are 0 index based (python list), so to correct this we introduced change to fix that.
> 
> > ```
> > for i in range(num_sfps):
> >         index = list_sfps[i]
> >         sfp = chassis.get_sfp(platform_api_conn, index)
> >         self.expect(sfp and sfp == sfp_list[i], "SFP {} is incorrect".format(i))
> > ```
> 
> it will always compare value returned by first index from list of indexes and first item in list from get_all_sfps
> 
> After this change it would work for both 0 based and 1 based or even if it is non continuous indexes.
> Hope this makes it more clear.

The SFP list will always start from index "0". See Ref:- https://github.com/Azure/sonic-platform-common/blob/master/sonic_platform_base/chassis_base.py#L473

chassis.get_sfp(0) should return SFP object corresponding to FIRST physical port, chassis.get_sfp(1) should return the SECOND physical port and so on. The abstract class doesn't talk about any mapping because the chassis object corresponding to a platform should take care of the internal mapping between SFP index and the physical port numbering. The common test relies upon the abstract class definition described and agreed upon by all platforms.

latestReviews.body: Looks good to me, thanks for working with me on this.

reviews.body:
Attached some comments for review. I am mostly concerned about the extensibility of this platform. I think it could be extremely powerful in giving testers granular control over the tests that are run and it could be extremely extensible for adding multiple criteria for skipping tests and defining the logic of how that occurs.

In order for that to happen though I think a few (relatively minor) changes should be made to the framework to enable developers to more easily develop criteria for skipping.
I made a couple comments that I would prefer to see addressed but if this needs to merge I don't think blocks it. Please let me know if there are any questions.
Looks good to me, thanks for working with me on this.
